FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

I've set the default video input to VGA on my monitor, I've tried wiggling the DisplayPort connector to see if it could be that (the connector doesn't click into my GPU's DP port properly), and the times the display has worked I've made sure that the resolution set is the same as my monitor's, but nothing results in a permanent fix; just a gamble as to whether or not it will display something.

I remember reading that depending on whether the adapter is active or passive (don't remember which one's which), there might not be a display. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90795625
json is fine, but the main reason against it is not performance but the possibility of corrupt data. For example if the server is updating the json file by writing it to disk and you happen to restart the program or server at that moment then the file can become corrupt. You can work around that with atomic file update but you need to know how to do that properly. sqlite does that automatically.

>>90792487
1. Names matter a little, e.g. a blank Elon Musk bot with just the name will still talk as Elon Musk, same for your name mattering a little e.g. some bots complain if you're "anon". I don't think the bot name being a title like "ship ai" or "babysitting a brat" really hurts but I think it's a waste of a field that can be easily used to remember a consistent name and add personality; I'm also pretty confident the names help even if they're not a celeb e.g. I'd expect a hoodrat bot called "Shaniqa" to perform a little better than one called "Margaret" and better still than one called "hrd6bebs Greg2$2". So call her Tabitha or Aubrey or something.
2. Fill out defs word count if you didn't yet, even mediocre examples copied and pasted from a chat give the bot some direction to fall back on during times of max uncertainty, you can always replace it later
3. you guys are very brave linking your web activity and/or email accounts with shit like this even if it's obviously ethically harmless, I hope you're using protection as it would be dumb to get blackmailed by hackers after CAI inevitably fucks up and leaks its treasure trove of user material

I have a Magneto Optical Disk drive that takes 90mm ISO disks (they were standardized for 128MB, 230MB, 640MB, 1.3 GB and 2.1GB).

They are a very cool technology, very reliable, surprised the tech didn't catch on in the US, instead we got Jazz and ZIP drives which sucked donkey dicks.

There are apparently people I've found who wither are pulling drives or hacking them somehow to have USB on the back with a power switch and modded firmware, so the Magneto Optical Drive just comes in looking like a USB floppy. You can get a new one from China for maybe 100USD, but I found some dude in Texas selling his for 54. Been having fun goofing around with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90783969
I game, I'm into game boy rom hacking and development, very interested in getting into FPGA dev, and this device makes me seethe beyond imagination.
How the fuck do you make a device like this for that price in current year and go out of your way to prevent piracy. Fuck, I can get over the firmware not being open source and literally being unable to replace the software on it (aside from the stuff on the "secondary" fpga), but these faggots literally built ROM loading into it, but it's only for GB/GBC (not GBA or any other supported system), AND they swapped the bit order of some registers to prevent ROMs not specifically made for it from working correctly (i.e. only ported homebrew or rom hacked commercial games load), and of course not all features are available for games loaded like this.
There's a """"jailbreak"""" for it, but it involves loading a core from the open source MiSTer project into the secondary FPGA, which not only is less accurate than the thing you paid out the ass for, but also lacks many of the advertised features of the main thing (with no way to implement those features since the secondary FPGA is restricted).
You literally need an extra fucking flashcart to get the most out of this shit, which are expensive as fuck as well, unless you shell out to the ezflash chinks with questionable hardware and RTC, and you're fucked if you want save states with any flashcart.
YOU'RE NOT NINTENDO YOU FUCKING FAGGOTS AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
THIS SHIT IS LITERALLY ANYTHING BUT MUH FUCKING PRESERVATION

The irony being that the freetard is right. NT isn't graphical - all it has is NtDisplayString().

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90709306
>There's no memory management API so you have to have some kind of automatic memory management.
False equivalence. Almost every implementation provides at least a function to free up memory manually (for instance, CCL:GC) and you often have implementation-specific control on the GC, which you can sometimes disable entirely. However, there is nothing mandating that memory management has to happen continuously, as the application runs and without explicit invocation by the programmer.

On a side note, C, at least in the language itself, has no concept of dynamic memory allocation at all, you can only allocate scope-based stack memory. malloc and free are standard library functions, whose behavior is ultimately platform-dependant (malloc could legally always return NULL, possibly to indicate that the underlying platform does not support dynamic allocation).

Plus, the C standard library may not be present at all on some implementations (think about freestanding environments).

Dynamic memory allocation and deallocation are much more platform-dependent than most people believe. A multiplatform programming language can offer at most some guidelines on how it might happen, but it cannot predict implementation-specific details.

>>90724143
>Is it possible to write a lisp in vim and run the file?
yes, you can even do it backwards and run vi/m from the repl and load the resulting file:
;; common lisp
(defparameter *ed-file* nil)

(defun vi (&optional (file *ed-file*) literal)
  (let* ((f (or file *ed-file*))
         (path (if literal file (concatenate 'string f ".lisp"))))
    (cond (f (setf *ed-file* f)
             (run-program "/bin/vi" (list "-l" path) :input t :output t)
             (if literal
                 :ok
                 (load path)))
          (t (error "no file, past or present")))))

(setf *ed-functions* (list #'vi))

;; scheme
(define ed
  (let ((local #f))
    (define (editor . file)
      (set! local (or local (car file)))
      (system* "vi" "-l" local))
      (load local))
    editor))

just add to the respective *rc for your lisp implementation

>The Clojure REPL gives the programmer an interactive development experience. When developing new functionality, it enables her to build programs first by performing small tasks manually, as if she were the computer, then gradually make them more and more automated, until the desired functionality is fully programmed. When debugging, the REPL makes the execution of her programs feel tangible: it enables the programmer to rapidly reproduce the problem, observe its symptoms closely, then improvise experiments to rapidly narrow down the cause of the bug and iterate towards a fix.

#lang sicp

(define (inc x) (+ x 1))
(define (identity x) x)

(define (accumulate combiner null-value term a next b)
  (if (> a b)
      null-value
      (combiner (term a)
                (accumulate term (next a) next b))))

(define (product term a next b)
  (accumulate * 1 term a next b))
(define (sum term a next b)
  (accumulate + 0 term a next b))

(defun samedi/eval-and-replace ()
  "Replaces the preceding sexp with its value."
  (interactive)
  (backward-kill-sexp)
  (condition-case nil
      (prin1 (eval (read (current-kill 0))) (current-buffer))
    (error
     (message "Invalid expression.")
     (insert (current-kill 0)))))

posts.com:
>>90757813
If only it were only that. Graham's books (in particular, ANSI Common Lisp) are full of outright incorrect information (for instance, see the chapter on LOOP), you're better off avoiding it altogether.

As crazy as it may sound, my unorthodox advice is to actually read the ANSI CL standard and largely ignore introductory books. It is the ultimate authority on how the language actually works and it is the least opinionated document you could ever find on it.

Of course, there is no substitute for practical experience. Reading is just one piece of the puzzle, you have to actually write programs in the language in order to truly learn it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90756287
Because the former gives you more possibilities. You have variable-sized and proportional fonts, better mouse support, images, more colors, toolbars, menubars, context menus, ability to distinguish character sequences outside of the limitations of termcaps and also a full terminal emulator inside it. Running Emacs in a terminal emulator loses all of these features.

Still, I generally run an entirely separate terminal emulator most of the time, I usually only run a shell directly within Emacs at most.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90758294
>Of course, there is no substitute for practical experience. Reading is just one piece of the puzzle, you have to actually write programs in the language in order to truly learn it.
You can get far by just doing some exercises on exercism and reading other people's solutions there.
Programming books are helpful if it's your first language or they're about algorithms or some other general computer science concept.
If you know how to program in general, you just need to get used to the syntax by writing a bit when encountering a new language.

As special as Lisp is, it's not that hard to get started. You can pick up the unique bits as you go.
I don't know how many times I've said this in this thread, but any book that pretends to teach you something without giving you *plenty* of exercises deserves to be thrown in the trash. It is not worth anyone's time and we should aggressively disparage it.

posts.com:
Anyone want to help me out with sicp 1.39? I am doing it recursively, counting up to k.
#lang sicp

; compute a k-term finite continuous fraction

(define (cont-frac n d k)
  (define (try i)
    (if (= i k)
        (/ (n i) (d i))
        (/ (n i) (+ (d i) (try (inc i))))))
  (try 1))

; calculate tan(x) as a k-term finite continuous fraction
(define (tan-cf x k)
  (cont-frac (lambda (i)
               (if (= i 1)
                   x
                   (* x x -1)))
             (lambda (i)
               (if (= i 1)
                   0
                   (- (* 2.0 (- i 1)) 1)))
             k))

(tan-cf 3.14 100)

I'm not getting accurate answers and the only other recursive solution I found doesn't work correctly either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90774311
nvm, fixed it.
(define (tan-cf x k)
  (/ x
     (+ 1
        (cont-frac (lambda (i)
                     (- (* x x)))
                   (lambda (i)
                     (+ 1 (* 2 i)))
                   k))))

>>90786827
What's funny is that Emacs' design isn't particularly novel, it just isn't deliberately crippled or complex. You don't realize how much developer freedom matters until it's gone. I've been trying to make a browser extension for personal use and there are obvious similarities (i.e. events/hooks), but the way it's done is just so fucking bad because it heavily limits what you can do, to the point where most of the time and effort goes into working around intentional constraints. There are no conveniences provided for you, you're expected to just write and parse HTML web pages instead of being given a proper UI framework. And this shit is LESS awful than most native UI programming.
I've pretty much decided that any future project I start will use Emacs as the UI, even if I don't write most of it in Elisp. Life is too short for this horseshit.

posts.com:
#lang sicp
(define tolerance 0.0001)
(define (fixed-point f first-guess)
  (define (close-enough? v1 v2)
    (< (abs (- v1 v2)) tolerance))
  (define (try guess)
    (let ((next (f guess)))
      (if (close-enough? guess next)
          next
          (try next))))
  (try first-guess))

(define (average x y) (/ (+ x y) 2))
(define (square x) (* x x))

(define (average-damp f) (lambda (x) (average x (f x))))

(define (compose f g)
  (lambda (x) (f (g x))))

(define (repeated f n)
  (if (= n 0)
      (lambda (x) x)
      (compose f (repeated f (- n 1)))))

(define (n-root-repeated n_power n_avg x)
  (fixed-point ((repeated average-damp n_avg)
                (lambda (y) (/ x (expt y (- n_power 1)))))
               1.0))
; tests
(n-root-repeated 2 1 100)                            
(n-root-repeated 3 1 100)                            
(n-root-repeated 4 2 100)                         
(n-root-repeated 5 2 100)                            
(n-root-repeated 6 1 100) ; -> converges with only 1 damping                            
(n-root-repeated 7 1 100)                            
(n-root-repeated 13 3 100)

I am working on exercise 1.45 of SICP. My test results don't match what I should be getting according to internet solutions. I am supposed to need one more damping at every power of 2, but almost every power converges with just one damping.

for instance, if i run delete-number on `(1 (2 (3 (2 (4))) 5) 6 (2)) it should output something like this (1 ((3 ((4))) 5) 6 ()) but what it actually does it outputs (1 3 4 5 6)

(defun delete-number (l a)
    (cond
        ; if the current atom is a number and equal to the given number a, then don't add it to the result
        ((and (equal l a) (numberp l)) nil)
        ; if the current atom is a number but not equal to the given number a, then add it to the result
        ((and (not (equal l a)) (numberp l)) (list l))
        ; if the current atom is a list, apply the function delete-number to the list and add it to the result
        (t (mapcan #'(lambda(x) (delete-number x a)) l))))

The midterm policy seems rather reasonable though. You're expected to show up to class every day, and you're expected to take the midterms when they are given. Professors have limited time to deal with as many students as they have, so they can't just give everyone their own personalized midterm exam that they can take at their leisure. Yes, you pay for your education, and you will receive it, but that doesn't mean you get to dictate the timing of everything. Nor does it mean you get unlimited chances, since part of what you are paying for is an accreditation.

I see your point, but it's garbage in the face of what education is by nature. It's not supposed to be a timed race, but rather an opportunity to learn the skills you want to learn (and pay for). Any proud educator would only want nothing more than to successfully educate someone (if that really is their passion).

Instead we have these "professors" that insecurely profess, more than anything else, not only their insecurity but even their ineptitude in their field by:

2. Not giving a fuck how effective their skills are in educating students by imposing restrictive and frankly bullshit policies like this.

Rushing your students along with deadlines and restrictions is not the mark of a proud and skilled educator, it's the brand of a fucking dipshit who has nothing more to offer his field than to bottleneck the eccentric and brilliant minds that invoke the most change, innovation, and out-of-the-box thinking that Stem fields need most right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792984

>it's not supposed to be a timed race
It isn't. You all make it to the finish line at the exact same time. If someone fails to do so, they take the course again.
>You should be able to take a test as many times as you need to get it right and pass the course, solidifying the effort and time it took you to do so.
Are you willing to pay extra for each additional time someone has to grade you? Because both the professors and the TAs have a lot more to do with their time.
>Any proud educator would only want nothing more than to successfully educate someone
University professors are educators second and researchers first. Teaching you is a side gig, not their main job. That's why they often have TAs paid for by the university to do their grading, hold office hours, and in some cases, even designing the homework. The TAs in turn, are typically grad students doing the bare minimum to get their tuition paid while they work on research. The only people who at a university whose primary job it is to educate people are adjunct professors. Adjuncts are paid garbage wages, given insane teaching loads, and have no job security. As much as they would love to give you all the time in the world, they do not have the luxury to hyperfocus on a student who needs to take a test several times to pass it.
>Not working in it (lmao ngmi)
Many professors, particularly in computer science, have prior experience in industry, and as mentioned before, their primary job is research.
>Rushing your students along with deadlines and restrictions
Many of those deadlines are imposed by the university itself. In case it wasn't clear, you're not the only person in the class. They can't center deadlines around you.

>>90749564
Updates on this keyboard, Skyloong GK75:
>It *is* gasket-mounted as advertised, but it is not a good gasket-mounting at all, very thin flaps of rubber that come up and over the plate from the silicone pad between the PCB and plate
>It's essentially tray-mounted, the PCB + plate assembly screws into standoffs molded into the bottom case
>It has a layer of foam inside the bottom case which is probably mostly to shield the two daughterboards that handle the USB-C port and the wireless, and the battery
>The spacebar split design is somewhat strangely split into three spacebars, the largest on the left, a slightly smaller one in the middle, and a Ctrl/Alt key sized one on the farthest right
>The knobs are T18 knurled but it'd probably be total hell to find another knob that fit, the shaft on the knob is insanely short to accommodate a molded plastic tube over it which fits the inserts on the knobs that the keyboard comes with. The knobs all have a guitar-style dial attached by default but it comes with two rounded GMMK Pro style knobs in a little baggy in case you want that style
>Box contains a C-female to A-female adapter, an A-male to C-male cable, split spacebar keys in Skyloong's GK2 rubber keycap profile, extra screws and knob heads, the switch-plate segment for split spacebar, a plastic dust cover, and a keycap/switch puller
>No complaints about the stabilizers at all! Stabs came pre-installed on both sets of spacebar plates, no rattle, all stabs are lubed from factory and they have a pretty good lube-job
>There's a QR code on the keyboard to download the shitty Epomaker/Skyloong customization software straight from its page, which is handy
I'm very pleased with it for the $79 asking price! I'll happily recommend it for anybody who wants an exploded 75% with knob, or wants a wireless 75%. You can get rid of the knob quickly and easily if you don't want it, or put on more knobs if you want more knobs. Also comes as an 1800 version called the GK980.

My switches just came in. They do feel nice and smooth but I'm not sure I like having the bump all the way at the top. I'd rather have it at the actuation point, but I guess I'll have to wait to actually type on it before making a definitive judgement.

Impressions on the case are that the homerow and thumb keys feel less awkward than I'd feared, but the edge of the thumb cluster is just a little in the way of my hand resting on the homerow. It's hard to say more until I have uniform keycaps. The OEM profile bottom row keys upside down fit but are almost perfectly flat with the OEM homerow keys (not really what I'm looking for from a contoured case), and OEM row 3 just doesn't fit right in any orientation. The angles are awkward and they bind up on the case when fully pressed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90788650
Most of these reviewers don't go into QMK/VIA or other configuration for these keyboards because it's boring, it's mainly about the wow factor and what features get put in. You can probably do anything you want with a knob that you can think of - at the end of the day it is just three keys bundled into one spot, left-turn/right-turn/-press - but reviewers in general won't talk about the knob because they care more that the knob is there than how to use it.

It also doesn't help that a lot of the interesting QMK stuff you can do requires you to know how it works (for programming it into firmware) and can't be done in VIA. And QMK itself is pretty esoteric software.

posts.com:
>>90788449
For a very general programming tutorial you could check out either HtdP or SICP, both of which use what is arguably the simplest real programming language (Lisp) so you maximize the time spent learning programming concepts and minimize the time spent on learning syntax.
https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/6-001-structure-and-interpretation-of-computer-programs-spring-2005/resources/1a-overview-and-introduction-to-lisp/

https://htdp.org

HtdP is generally considered easier to get into, but for SICP there are countless video recordings of lectures that use SICP as the text book.

Another approach is to use Assembly as your first programming language, so that you get intimately familiar with stuff like memory management, pointers, registers, binary logic and data representation early on, removing these things as possible stumbling blocks when learning higher-level languages. Some books that teach assembly without assuming prior programming knowledge are "Assmbly Coding in Color: ARM and NEON" and "Programming From The Ground Up"
https://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/pgubook

>ppl tell me python or java since their newfag friendly, but are they languages used in freetard projecst?
Python is used in a lot of open source projects, Java much less so. I also don't think that Java is particularly newfag-friendly.
The GNU Project stuff is mostly written in C and uses Lisp for less performance-critical tasks (e.g. Gimp and Guix use Lisp as their main scripting language, Emacs has its own dialect of Lisp).

posts.name: xolatile
posts.com:
>>90794449
extern signed long int read  (signed int,       void *, unsigned long int);
extern signed long int write (signed int, const void *, unsigned long int);

extern signed int open  (const char *, signed int);
extern signed int close (              signed int);

signed int main (argc, argv)
const signed int     argc;
const char       * * argv; {
    signed        int file = - 1;
    signed   long int stop = + 1;
             char     a    = '0';
             char     z    = '0';
    unsigned char     data = (unsigned char) 0X00;

    if (argc != 2)
        return (0XA0);

    if ((file = open (* (argv + 1), 0)) == - 1)
        return (0XF2);

    loop:

    if ((stop = read (file, & data, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (data == (unsigned char) 0X90)
        (void) write (1, "\n", (unsigned long int) 1);

    a = (char) ((signed int) data / 16);
    z = (char) ((signed int) data % 16);

    a += (a > (char) 9) ? (char) ((signed int) 'A' - 10) : '0';
    z += (z > (char) 9) ? (char) ((signed int) 'A' - 10) : '0';

    (void) write (1, & a, (unsigned long int) 1);
    (void) write (1, & z, (unsigned long int) 1);
    (void) write (1, " ", (unsigned long int) 1);

    if (stop > (signed long int) 0)
        goto loop;

    exit:

    (void) write (1, "\n", (unsigned long int) 1);

    if (close (file) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    return (0X3C);
}

Example of "clean C" code, it's rather hardcore...

posts.name: xolatile
posts.com:
>>90794605
It's my little invention called "nop" program.
When I learned assembly and (ELF64 / x86_64 / IA32e) machine code, I used to place 'nop' instruction before each assembly instruction.
Then you assemble that source code with Flat Assembler, and run 'nop my_executable', to print machine code for each instruction in new line.
The program 'nop' just reads the file, and if byte is equal to 144 (0X90), it prints a new line. I know, it's just "literally 3 cloc" in Python etc. (:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
been using this thing for a month
a chink eink ui bolted on top an android 11 ("library" is literary hacked into the launcher, setting up a wallpaper behind icon grid is intentionally broken to show plain white)
can install anything from fdroid
don't expect something like lineage to ever run on this due to being obscure and the proprietary drivers
5 responsiveness/resolution modes from crisp and slow to ghosting & dithered and less slow
normal android settings menu and file manager hidden but can be accessed from a custom launcher
to "opt out" of some of the spying you need to access those hidden normal android settings
most settings are accessible in the chink ui though
wonky default combination and multiple options of virtual navigation buttons and gestures, takes couple of weeks of tweaking settings to get truly comfortable with
default document reader program is very good, can write in pdfs with the pen (instant feedback), also takes time to get used to and tweak
clock is never right (unless connected to internet) and alarm is unusable due to the hardcore power-saving
cold and warm backlight whose intensities can be mixed
can read in bright sun without the backlight (awesome)
if you want to view the opened documents in the task switcher you must open them from the stock "library" app, which does not show in other launchers, so you are basically stuck with the default chinky launcher
being able to snap the and firmly hold pen on the edge of the device is underrated
the plain cover that comes with the device is crap because it doesn't snap together when opened, just flaps about unless you hold it
the more expensive keyboard cover is good at being a cover and snaps together when opened, also provides slight corner protection. keyboard connects via magnetic 5pin apple-charger looking connector instead of bt, doesn't require a battery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90782939
The nice thing about e-ink is that it doesn't need to refresh at all. Constantly refreshing like an CRT is completely pointless.
The problem with the refresh speed on e-ink is that you have physical pigments suspended in a liquid that have to move. The fact that you can get a response time of under 20ms with local refreshes is astonishing.
Color makes it far more complicated since you have four different pigments instead of two for ACEP/Gallery. This makes aligning them with electricity a lot more complicated.
The alternative is Kaleido which is using a color filter array like with LCD but that cuts into the brightness since you have no backlight to counter it and into the resolution. The amount and quality of colors is also worse.

>Thats why there's a "skills shortage" - because the barriers for entry are made too high and no one wants to hire anyone. But that won't change just because there's a shortage.
Part of the problem is there's a huge gap in the education market for software developers. You can either go get a degree in Computer Science or go to a bootcamp (or be self taught, but I'm not getting into that here). CS degrees are way too theoretical for the work that jobs require, and bootcamps are way too simplified for what companies expect. The only way to fill that gap in is to get experience. It's like if the real estate development industry wanted to put up buildings, but the education system was only producing materials physicists and carpenters. Though the problem with that metaphor is that carpenter and physicist are different roles and jobs, along with architect and structural engineer... and no one on any real project is expected to do all of them. The software field is too young and immature to have that level of specialization yet.

>>90786416
What I do is have one master resume that has all of my previous jobs and bullets for all of them. I include side projects too. It's like 4 pages long. Then, when I'm job hunting, I open it up, add any new stuff for my current job, do a little editing to update terminology for old jobs, and then make a copy and start trimming to one page. Sometimes I'll do a unique version for a specific job, but most of the time I just use one version for multiple applications. What I leave in depends on the type of jobs I'm looking for at the time... which could even mean a bullet from 5 years ago stays.
Remember: there's no universe resume template that you HAVE TO follow. It's a sales document for you, your skills, and your experience. You can present it in whatever way YOU think will give the best impression. Just don't flat out lie

There's no thought put into any of this, these things just happened through the natural flow of life, no "getting into" necessary. That's what happens when you're not a non-programming freak, you don't ever find yourself one night lying in bed alone wondering why you don't have an interest in programming. You don't devise a plan to stop touching your cock for six months in order to look learn a programming language. You just exist, you go with the societal flow, and you end up with an interest in programming and knowledge of multiple programming languages in high school and college, then a 6 figure work from home software engineering job. If you missed out on this flow, it's probably because you're a non-programmer.

>>90783321
>Don't be addicted to technology yourself
>Only let them use technology along with you when they're young
Want to keep your kids to an hour or two of screen time per day? Share the same time with them, and when it's time to get off, tell them it's time to pause because you have to go do the dishes or whatever and you don't want to miss anything. Also, invite your kids to help you do the dishes, and let them actually help even when it makes it take longer and get worse results. They'll learn how to be more efficient eventually, and more importantly, they'll build the habit of doing the chores because the chores have to be done. What you don't want is the habit of doing the chores because they're told to; that'll be a huge pain in the ass when they're teenagers and looking for reasons not to do as they're told.

The big thing is to never ever use your phone or TV as a babysitter. That is exactly the kind of mindless consooming that you're trying to avoid. The other big thing is to not be addicted yourself. They will learn from your behaviors, and if they see you shitposting on /g/ for 20 hours a day, they will pick up the same habit. I'd even recommend brushing your teeth and going to bed at the same time that they do. That way, it shows then that adulthood is not about being above the rules and staying up all night is not something to aspire to; rather, if they want to show how grown up they are, they should be dutiful and attentive to their own health and wellbeing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90783321
Didn't read the replies in the thread since they'll all be /pol/ tier psychotic garbage, here's an actual answer:

1) Trying to force your kid not to use technology with nanny software, time gates, etc doesn't work.
You probably have responsibilities and obligations, your kid does not, your kid will spend all their time defeating it which may include going to a friend's house.
Additionally any time you tell a child "don't do this or else" you make them want to do it because they think you're keeping something good from them.

2) You need to offer better, more engaging, more fun alternatives. Fishing, camping, skiing, tennis, building a boat by hand, whatever just try every kind of thing there is until you find one your kid is good at, then encourage it.
Learn it along side your kid, even if just a tiny bit, so you can keep coaching and encouraging your kid to pursue it.

3) Kids use technology in place of friends or social interaction or whatever because it's easy, gratifying, all their friends are their already, and all their friendships are superficial and dangerous (kids bully and betray each other constantly).
4) once you find the thing your kid is good at, ask them if they'd like to go to a camp, training seminar, or whatever related to it where they can meet other kids.

5) Try to explain things in a way to your child that allows them to make a choice, while understanding WHY your desired behavior represents something they may find favorable.
"Technology will rot your brain, you don't want to become a tranny do you?" is worthless.
"I think you'll like other stuff even more than technology, you'll find technology is still something you need to use and important but you'll know about way better stuff that your classmates don't know about."

See the difference?

    read_upper_4_bits:

    if ((stop = read (input, & a, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (a == ' ' || a == '	' || a == '
')
        goto read_upper_4_bits;

    if (a >= '0' && a <= '9')
        data = (unsigned char) ((unsigned int) (a - '0') << 4);
    else if (a >= 'A' && a <= 'F')
        data = (unsigned char) ((unsigned int) (a - 'A' + '
') << 4);
    else
        return (0XEE);

    read_lower_4_bits:

    if ((stop = read (input, & z, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (z == ' ' || z == '	' || z == '
')
        goto read_lower_4_bits;

    if (z >= '0' && z <= '9')
        data |= (unsigned char) (z - '0');
    else if (z >= 'A' && z <= 'F')
        data |= (unsigned char) (z - 'A' + '
');
    else
        return (0XEE);

    (void) write (output, & data, (unsigned long int) 1);

    if (stop > (signed long int) 0)
        goto loop;

    exit:

    if (close (input) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    if (close (output) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    return (0X3C);
}

This is perfectly valid, completely warning free C code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90751539
>Just the standards

So, for basic effects, the industry standards are:

>Waves (the boomer choice as they were already in the plugin game 30 years ago, but the gigantic number of plugins can be overwhelming for a beginner)
>FabFilter (the modern choice, just a few plugins with zero bloat and a neat interface, used by everyone, can never go wrong with it)
>iZotope (more used for special applications like mastering, audio restoration…)
>for reverb, Valhalla (affordable + no bullshit interface + sounds amazing)

And that’s it. So it would make sense for you to go with the FabFilter bundle + maybe a Valhalla reverb (ValhallaRoom or ValhallaVintageVerb) or the old Altiverb if you like it better. People can suggest 5,000 other plugins that are cheaper, marginally better or whatever like ToneBoosters, Plugin Alliance, DMG Audio and so on, but these are the ubiquitous ones. Walk into any studio in the world and the engineer will likely have Waves and/or FabFilter plugins. Need tutorials or tips? YouTube is full of videos showcasing these plugins, etc.

Also I’d rather rely on these third-party plugins than on FL Studio ones for standard effects (the latter are okay and serviceable, but not great like, say, FabFilter Pro-Q or ValhallaRoom).

Why do you want another DAW? It’s usually best to stick with what you know. I can understand that you want a completely fresh approach after a break though. I did the same myself. As a previous FL Studio user who was back into music-making, this was my path:

>Reaper (felt miserable as you explained)
>Studio One (very neat and pleasant to use, but the bundled content is kinda meh)
>Logic Pro, which I still use now (less snappy to use than Studio One, but having god-tier stock sounds and plugins, a beautiful UI, countless forum topics and videos covering every single question you could have, deep options with MIDI or the Environment… makes it an even better and more productive experience overall)

I tried FL Studio again after that, but wouldn’t trade Logic or even Studio One for it nowadays.

Also, Ableton Live is the most popular DAW today, and everyone should try it, but it did nothing for me so I can’t recommend it personally.

posts.com:
>>90774833
I have found it very helpful to ignore the Pattern Sequencer completely when creating a song on the timeline. That means loading all your instruments from the playlist (which will automatically assign a track to the mixer and creates a pattern named after the instrument). By creating all new clips in the timeline you are able to dynamically change pattern sizes based on how you resize them in the playlist.

The pattern sequencer is good to work in when you are specifically creating patterns that you might use for live performance or something like that. Once I stopped thinking about the pattern sequencer and started working almost exclusively in the playlist everything clicked. Hope this makes sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Maybe to more properly define what an avant-garde track would be, we should look at what we know is not avant-garde. For example, 4/4 time isn't very avant-garde, neither is tonal music, or tracks that have a pop/rock structure where there are A and B sections that are different but clearly related to eachother. But obviously we need to draw the line somewhere— what was known as avant-garde 70 years ago would've been something like Schaeffer or Stockhausen, but that stuff is too simple to make with today's technology so it wouldn't fit the description. I know this discussion has probably been done to death, but like John Cage says, experimental music is when you don't know what the outcome is going to be, so copying avant-garde music from the past could not be considered experimental, or forward-thinking, by that definition. What would be avant-garde today would probably something that relates to weird and original ways of using digital effects, but if it were so easy to come up with something original I would have a track ready by now.

>>90795028
 
new_list = []
for e2 in e1:
    new_list.append(666 if e2 == "satan" else e2)


This code will iterate through each element in the list e1 and check if it is equal to the string "satan". If it is, it will append the value 666 to the new_list. If it is not, it will append the element itself to the new_list.

This is equivalent to the original code using a lambda function and map(), but it does not use these functional programming constructs.

>>90787343
The thing with C is, that understanding it, helps you a lot with stuff like kernel development, compiler development, decompiling and similar stuff. I have not studied CS, but as far as I know, most CS graduates have at least a rudimentary understanding of C. It's just knowledge people assume to have. You do not need to be very good at it, but looking at a C code snippet and understanding it is a very valuable skill. C++ on the other hand is something very different, I personally do not like it, but there are many people who like it very much, in particular many C programmers consider it having features, that C misses. People often meantion C and C++ in one sentence, but in reality those languages are very different. It's true that you can compile a C program with a C++ compiler, but good C++ code is very different from good C code. If you are getting into compsci, I recommend you learning at least basic C. People often claim C is very hard to get into, but that is wrong. If you start with compsci from the ground up, C will be very inituitive and easy to understand. Contrary to C++, it's simple and "clean", C++ is verbose and not as readable (and quite ugly in my humble opinion, but that's what I think).

If you want to start learning either of those languages, start looking for books on libgen or similar sites, look what book you like the best and start reading it. If you can't learn from books at all, watch youtube tutorials, there are plenty. If you are inpatient and do not want to learn C, before C++, maybe because Uni wants you to this way, for whatever reason, then go to "learncpp.com", it is considered a very good website to learn C++ from, with a great reputation. Good luck on your journey, anon.

Would it be a mistake to use Rails for a new project in 2023?

Points in favour:
>I know how to use it
>It has great stuff built in like an easy to use ORM
>It has Turbo enabled by default in Rails 7, which basically makes your site run like an SPA (loading just the parts of your page that change with JavaScript), but without you having to write your whole front-end in React
>I'm pretty sure GitHub still runs on it and GitLab too, so if it's fast enough for them then it should be fast enough for me

Using CSS in 2023 is considered harmful because it's impossible to avoid class collisions at scale and it's not modular or reusable so it's incompatible with modern component frameworks. You must use a compiler like SCSS or, preferably, CSS in JS so that you can check your styling into source control with your other component code

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90788151
ipID, ipStr, firstVisit, lastVisit
>(unsigned AI int, varchar, datetime, datetime null)
agentID, agentStr, firstVisit, lastVisit
>(unsigned AI int, varchar, datetime, datetime null)
hitID, ipID, agentID, URI, referrer, datetime
>(unsigned AI int, unsigned int, unsigned int, varchar, varchar, datetime)

There are some tables you could use, put it in its own DB separate from your main stuff, you could also do something like creating new table(s) for every new month and containing by month so it's easier to manage. On each page load, you update relevant rows and do your hits table insert with the page URI and the http referrer (skipping that extra info in IP/agent tables would reduce overhead on page loads though).

Then create a cron job or scheduled task to run a script that counts the monthly hits and update totals/averages/etc in some sort of "total stats" or "monthly stats" table (e.g. counting how many page hits for each unique URI [you might want to split before any ? or #, or record ?get differently] and storing that in a table), saving and updating whatever info you want, and setting this to run when your server is at its lowest usage (or hourly or w/e). You can also make that script runable on demand from your admin pages (to get up and running before dealing with cron/schedulers or just to update on demand).
1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90788151
>>90789118
You could write text files instead of using a DB as well, if you don't run one or don't want to. This was the basic layout of the tables I was going to make for mine, haven't gotten around to implementing stats yet so you might find yourself wanting to do something different (as might I). For example, you could add "hitCount" to the IP and agent tables to make some of this easier or give you more info at a glance; but the more info you have to update with those rows the more overhead you're giving yourself for every page hit. Bare min, you could get away with only the ID and strings for those tables. You could also put it all in one table, but there'd be a lot of duplicate data in the IP and agent columns. And don't forget to clean input.
2/2

posts.com:
>>90790064
to clarify, the best database wrapper is exactly this:

function do($query, $args) {
  $pdo->statement->execute($query, $args);
}

function multi($query, $args) {
  return $this->do->fetchAllAssoc();
}

function row($query, $args) {
  $ref = $this->do->fetchAllAssoc();
  foreach ($ref as $row){
    return $row;
  }
}

function single($query, $args) {
  $ref = $this->do->fetchAllAssoc();
  foreach ($ref as $row) {
    foreach ($row as $value) {
      return $value
    }
  }
}

posts.com:
I want to make a multiplayer tabletop game or maybe a card game. Something akin to monopoly. Would javascript and webdev shit be enough or do I need to learn game engine like unity and some networking library?
Is nodejs good for making a multiplayer legame?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792006
Since you're using var (you should never be using var), the "file" value is able to be changed at any point.

TS doesn't know when the callback function will be called (i.e. 
old => [...old, file]
), it could be in a minute, and any time in between, the var file can change

Solution: change the variable to a const assignment. Ideally you should be using const assignments for most variable assignments (instead of lets and vars), unless there's very good reason you're reassigning variables.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792680

I haven't used mongodb in years, but the general idea for document dbs is to not use joins (relations) like you are here. Everything is mostly non-normalized for max read performance, but the issue with nosql db collections lies here because access patterns, new features, and refactors may require different collection structures which results in complex migrations.

For this implementation, I'd just have all the post objects inside the threads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90794924
I was thinking grid over flex myself, from my understanding of grid I should be able to split a section into a grid of equally spaced squares and set the start and end point of various elements allowing overflow over a set amount of grid spaces.

>what can you tell us about your design, any tips?

I'm not a fan of clutter and things that don't serve a purpose. I like minimalism and empty space, that's an influence for a lot of my photography and design.

I thought about what the purpose of the site was (convey information, show competent design) and how best to get that purpose across efficiently.

A lot of sites I looked at love using fancy graphics to fill up space, lots of distracting colours, animations that serve no real purpose etc. I felt those would distract from the main purpose of conveying information.

Best tip I could give in terms of design (with my style) is really break it down. What is the purpose? What's the best way to achieve this? Dose x element add or distract from that? Look at the design from an outside perspective, dose it work to achieve your goal? Is there anything missing or distracting? Play around with shapes and spaces with what you have, think about how the (western) eye travels across the page (left to right), consider the order in which it lands at certain elements and if that's conducive to what you're conveying.

If you are interested in any other art from (photography, painting, drawing etc) practice it more.

>>90782313
Old digital cameras use a CCD image sensor, which is a far more mature technology that produces more consistent results.

The sensor is exposed to light, and the reading are dumped to a processing chip that translates those readings into RGB values, taking exposure and the overall scene dynamics into account. This readout is nearly instantanious so it doesn't produce the shutter roll effect like CMOS.

Modern cameras use CMOS sensors. They were originally adopted because they could be made using the same equipment as other ICs, as opposed to CCD which requires separate machinery. It also supposedly uses less energy, which is ideal for battery powered applications. Due to the physical characteristics if CMOS vs CCD, it is less sensitive to light per unit of area. Also, the way CMOS works is each pixel translates its input into an RGB value independently without taking the other pixels into account. The result is a lot more RGB noise since the readings aren't being normalized against each other to form a coherent image. Each row of pixels is queried one by one, so the top row is going to be several milliseconds behind the bottom row, producing a skewed image during high motion scenes.

CMOS has come a long way since its inception. The design has been greatly improved to compensate for inherently poor low light performance and noise floor, at the expense of requiring special processes beyond standard IC, defeating the cost benefits over CCD. External image processors help level out the noisy RGB floor, at the expense of added complexity and increased energy consumption, negating the energy advantage over CCD.

All this just to match CCD tech from 20 years ago. Professional applications still use CCD if that gives you an idea of which one is actually better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90793164

You mean because of LLVM? LLVM IR is a representation of machine code that is independent of the source language. x86 machine code is also independent of the source language, as are many other instruction sets. Just because LLVM IR is not x86 machine code doesn't mean "rustc" isn't a compiler.

Is Clang a C compiler? All it does is generate LLVM IR. Not even "real" machine code. So, LLVM IR is a perfectly valid target for a compiler to compile to. Clang and Rust are both compilers, even though they're just frontends for LLVM, which takes the further step of lowering the IR to machine code.

Post build list or current specs including MONITOR: https://pcpartpicker.com/

>NEWS
New releases: Zen 4X3D, RTX 4070Ti, 7900XT/X, RTX 4090, 4080, AM5 / Zen 4; Intel Arc GPUs A770 and A750

>RECOMMENDED CPUs**
HTPC(4K60)/Web Browsing: i3 10105, i3 12100
Budget: i5 13400F, R5 7600 (whichever is cheapest)
Midrange: 7800X3D
High End: 7950X/3D, 7900X/3D
Ultra-High End: Threadripper (wait for them to be updated)

>RECOMMENDED GPU PERFORMANCE LEVEL
Do NOT buy from any second hand sources (it is either scalped or used).
1440p: RX 6800/XT, RTX 3080; budget: RX 6650XT, RTX 3060 Ti FE, RX 6700 XT
2160p: RTX 4090, 7900XTX; alternative: RX 6950/XT, RTX 3090, budget: RTX 3080 12GB, RX 6800/XT
Amateur production: RTX 4090, RTX 3090 (compute+VRAM)

>RECOMMENDED RAM
Budget: 16gb DDR4 3600 MT/s CL18, CL14 with Ryzen for CPU limited games
Standard: 32gb DDR5 6000 MT/s CL30, strongly advised to avoid mixing xmp kits
High end: 64gb+ DDR5 6000 MT/s CL30, strongly advised to avoid mixing xmp kits.

>RECOMMENDED PSUs
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

>RECOMMENDED CASES
One that looks good

>RECOMMENDED SSDs
Standouts: Sabrent Rocket 4 Plus, Crucial P5 Plus, Kingston KC3000
https://ssd.borecraft.com/

>RECOMMENDED GAMING MONITORS
Avoid OLED TVs. Keep pixel density in mind when choosing a monitor size (137+ PPI is good, ~200 is ideal though rare and expensive).
Budget: 1440p 144hz+ IPS panel
Standard: 4k 144hz+ IPS panel. At this tier the basic 4k 144hz panels (8bit + FRC dithering) go for about 400-500, while the ones with pro-level color (true 10bit panels) go for roughly 1k.
High end: High refresh rate 4k panels with MiniLED, g-sync ultimate modules, 10-bit, and so on (PG32UQX is the best currently). Look for VESA DisplayHDR 1400 certification.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90759788
As I said, it's all 3 for 6$ deals, so everything cost effectively 2$ each.
1. Aux Bluetooth receiver - haven't tested it yet, but it looks fine. Buttons feels suprisingly satisfying. MicroUSB cable is ultra short, which was to be expected. Pretty good for the price.
2. 100 chinese bandaids. Might give me band-aids. Time will tell.
3. A very nice little pouch. Comes well packaged with one main compartment and one outer compartment that stretches to fit larger items. Attaches to a belt or molle system. Comes with a carabiner and foam inside so it keeps its form in transport, pleasantly surprised by the quality. Buckle is cheap plastic though. I'd have preferred it without the "sport" on it, but very happy for 2$.
4. Plush shark. I have since learned that plush sharks are a lbtq thing, but whatever. It's cute and it was 2$. Can't complain.
5. Wine stoppers, 2 pcs. Got them as gifts, they should do the job. Enough to keep flies out at least.
6. Folding rubber band gun with rubber bands. The front attachment hook for the rubber bands isn't big enough, so you can't load more than 4 bands at once into the revolver, but other than that it's nice. Might get a second as a gift so I can shoot a friend whenever we meet each other.
7. Chinese lego set. Not sure yet if it'll be a gift or if I will build it myself. If I do, I will report back.
8. Metal hooks. They do what they say, no complaints here.
9. 2m LED strip with motion sensor. I hope the motion sensor works well, but I can't test it at the moment.
10. 5 of those "eternal pencil leads". No idea how well they will work, I hope it's not a normal pencil lead or else it'll be real annoying to sharpen once it wears off.
11. A plant sprayer that attaches to PET bottles. Looks like it'll work and will be great help for the upcoming spring in the garden. Very nice.
(cont)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90760165
(cont)
12. "multitool". It's very small, but that was to be expected. The knife on it is short and dull as shit, but nothing that a few minutes on a sharpening stone couldn't fix. It does have springs that make using the plier part more enjoyable. Since it's so small it could be a nice thing to carry with you when space and weight are at a premium. I do not have too high hopes for the carbon content of the steel, probably going to be very soft and dull quickly.
13. USB-C (M) to MicroUSB (F), USB-A (M) to USB-C(F) and USB-C(M) to USB-A(F) adapters. All advertised as "USB 3.0" and surprisingly the USB ports do have the appropriate amount of pins. Did not expect that. Quite handy.
14. Electronics organizer. Quite a lot bigger than I expected, but I like it. A neon green inside that makes you retinas bleed, but good sectioning.
15. A generic x-acto knife with replacement blades. Very nice.

Overall, very happy with the stuff. Not a single item in there that feels super cheaply made or like it would work badly.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90760736
Last picture, from the other side this time. This set was very fun to build honestly, I might get more now. Also nice of them to include a disassembly tool, since disassembling lego without it is a pain in the ass and the set requires you to rebuild stuff.
Only thing left to do in that pic is adding the stickers. It's nice that they include them and all but one are great, but one of the stickers is ever so slightly larger than the piece it should be added on and that triggered the fuck out of me. I cut the sticker to size with the x-acto knife.
>>90760746
Hard to quantify since I haven't played with lego in ages. The plastic feels "cheaper", but not much. Like the pieces have a little more give than lego used to. But that may also be because it's ages and I use more force now or some shit. All the parts except that piston feel like normal generic lego parts, no weird pieces here. I also wouldn't be surprised if they were compatible with lego. I don't have any to compare, but they seem the same size that lego used to be. Overall, mabe 90% of the way to real lego. In a side by side I may be able to tell it's a copy, but without that reference it's really hard to tell. Also the parts being a bit lighter and probably made from another plastic did not impact the assembly part at all in terms of feel.

It's like if to stop minors from burning gacha in vidya a law was passed that requires real ID for every online game. Why not, you know, ban or heavily regulate gambling in vidya ? Sadly as far as online surveillance goes there's not many whitepills. It gets worse every year. Solutions to bypass these things will always exist and come out, but that keeps adding more steps to shit that was convenient to do just years ago.
The solution is really to gather with your friends on trustworthy environments, do cost effective measures to get past the 14 eyes and just live your life trying not to lose sleep over this. It's not healthy to get obsessed over what you can't change. Worry about what you can do, do it, and give little care for the rest.

>>90783766
>What went wrong?
Its market niche shrank. Other profitable media products also became replaced by products or software which Circuit City didn't sell profitably.. For a time, CC tried to create a DVI standard for "DVD type video" and it spent a lot of money. These video discs used the video as a service concept, thus, their DVI types of DVD video discs expired and self destructed after you started viewing them. Thus, you could buy movies and TV show video discs that had service features such as "Watch One Time" or "Watch for Up To One Week". After the condition was satisfied, the DVI disc self-destructed.

After CC put out such a creation, I vowed never to buy from CC retail stores again. And many other people did the same thus hatening the demise of the company.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm trying to use Linux Mint for some basic gaming with an AMD APU, what do I need to look for? Just make sure I have an updated version of Mesa drivers through a trustworthy PPA?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772369
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:kisak/kisak-mesa && sudo dpkg --add-architecture i386 && sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade && sudo apt install libgl1-mesa-dri:i386 mesa-vulkan-drivers mesa-vulkan-drivers:i386

Run this command and you should be all set.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772388
Also you gotta restart after you run it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772388
Thank you, bro! For learning purposes: is it kinda like I posted? It seems like a PPA is added and Mesa drivers are being installed from it, plus enabling 32bit architecture. I'm a newbie, so I'm not sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90772418
Yes, it's adding the Kisak Mesa repo which has the most up to date Mesa drivers for Ubuntu-based systems, telling dpkg to add 32-bit architecture support, updating the repo sources, fully upgrading anything that can be upgraded then installs the Mesa and Vulkan drivers from the Kisak repo. Then like I said just restart the PC and you should be all good for gaming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90773054
>deleting stuff outside pwd
Assuming both folders you mentioned are in your home directory (/home/user) it would be 
rm -r ~/Documents/'Testicle Boxing'

and 
rm -r ~/Videos/Abuela

If they have files/folders inside of them, otherwise replace the rm -r for rmdir.
~ is a shortcut to your home directory. You could also use absolute paths (/home/user/Documents/etc) or relative paths:
Pretend you're in ~/Downloads, you can type .. to go up a folder so from ~/Downloads you would enter
rm -r ../Documents/'Testicle Boxing'

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90773462
It's actually the safest way to dual-boot if you want to install the Linux distro on a separate drive to your Windows one. That way the Windows one doesn't get pissy about it sharing space with another OS.
Just make sure that you're installing Linux to the fresh other drive which you can easily see by looking at the drives in something like gparted or the Ubuntu installer. You'll know which one is which by the MS partitions on whatever drive, which'll probably be /dev/sda or /dev/nvme01n1 if it's an M.2 SSD.

>>90773535
I ran these commands
Remove all the configuration files in /etc/pipewire (sudo mv /etc/pipewire /tmp)

Reinstall pipewire, pipewire-pulse, and pipewire-media-session (sudo pacman -S pipewire pipewire-pulse pipewire-media-session)

Enable and start the relevant services (systemctl --user enable pipewire pipewire-pulse pipewire-media-session) and (systemctl --user restart pipewire pipewire-pulse pipewire-media-session).

How to do fresh install of linux without deleting /home directory?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90780982
You can easily just alias a grub-install and grub-mkconfig command into a single word like "regrub" or "refreshgrub" that you could run every time GRUB updates for peace of mind.

>>90781059
Having /home on a separate partition so you can erase / but /home stays intact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90781059
You need to back it up to another drive. Most distros are going to want to format your entire drive (or at least format the root partition). This is why a lot of people recommend using a separate /home partition if you're going to be installing multiple distros.
BTRFS with a separate home subvolume may also work but no guarantees.

>>90783363
SIGKILL is stronger, the default pkill/kill signal is SIGTERM, which is essentially asking nicely for a process to die. SIGKILL is exactly as it sounds, kill the process, any potential data loss be damned. SIGKILL is useful if something's completely stuck.
FYI, you almost certainly need root/sudo privileges to kill another user's session.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90785757
>Is it worth it to spend time learning vim/emacs
Definitely. The great thing about vim is that the keybindings are extremely portable--a ton of different editors have vim-emulation modes (like emacs evil mode), and in the case of vscode, you can even embed a full neovim instance inside of it. Pretty much every tiling window manager and a ton of different terminal applications use vim-like keybindings. You can get an extension for any of the major browsers that gives them vim keybindings. You can enable a vi-mode in bash/fish/zsh that allows you to move through and edit your commands with vi bindings, and applications like tmux (and I believe alacritty) allow you to move through the entire terminal buffer and copy text with vi keybindings. It's pretty sweet.

Some of the emacs keybindings aren't too bad to learn, either (like C-f, C-b, C-n, C-p). They're handy for movement in insert mode, and there are quite a few programs that implement them as well (I believe MacOS has some system-wide emacs navigation feature).

>>90786955
It seems that it allows for more functions than just changing the keys
I didnt even know my caps key was super when held
#!/bin/sh

# This script is called on startup to remap keys.
# Decrease key repeat delay to 300ms and increase key repeat rate to 50 per second.
xset r rate 300 50
# Map the caps lock key to super, and map the menu key to right super.
setxkbmap -option caps:super,altwin:menu_win
# When caps lock is pressed only once, treat it as escape.
killall xcape 2>/dev/null ; xcape -e 'Super_L=Escape'
# Turn off caps lock if on since there is no longer a key for it.
xset -q | grep "Caps Lock:\s*on" && xdotool key Caps_Lock

>>90794473
Certainly. Your mpv config might be different, and I use a mix of relative and absolute paths for easier matching by fzy and to play it nice with playlistmanager, so you might need to adjust it. Also I'm using konsole as my terminal emulator and -l 34 forces a particular terminal window size, blah, blah, blah. Just read it before copying.
#!/bin/bash

cd ~ 
file="$(find Music/ Videos/ Downloads/ -print | fzy -l 34)"
file="$(readlink -f "$file")"
[ -z "$file" ] && exit

if [ -z "$1" ]; then
  mpv --pause=no "$file"
else
  setsid -f mpv --pause=no "$file"
fi

local mp = require 'mp'

local function fzy()
    local handle = io.popen(
        "konsole -e sh -c 'cd ~ " .. 
        "&& readlink -f \"$(find Music/ Videos/ Downloads/ -print | fzy -l 34)\"" ..
        ">| /tmp/mpv/ff-filename || rm /tmp/mpv/ff-filename -f'"
        ):read("*all")
    local file = io.open("/tmp/mpv/ff-filename")
    if file == nil then return nil end
    return string.sub(file:read("a"), 1, -2)
end

local function ff(mode)
    local filename = fzy()
    if filename == nil then 
        mp.osd_message("No file selected")
        return 
    end
    local append = mode == 'append'
    mp.osd_message((append and 'Appending' or 'Opening') .. ' file: ' .. filename)
    mp.commandv('loadfile', filename, (append and 'append-play' or 'replace'))
end

mp.register_script_message('ff', ff)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90791897
i tried a couple external DACs but the audio latency on them is brutal
you can test it by plugging some headphones/speakers into the device to be tested, as well as a microphone, and placing the mic right next to the headphone. get into a game and, with your mouse right next to the mic and headphone, click loudly. in recording software like Audacity, the difference between the noise of the mouse button clicking IRL, vs shooting sounds being emitted from the headphones, is your button-to-audio delay

once you do this you find that the difference in latency between devices is frankly unbelievable. it can be 100ms+
although internal soundcards all use USB-based DACs, they are at least latency optimized (at least the couple i tested)

What's a good CPU cooler to tame a 5900x? Beyond the usual day-to-day mild use, I primarily plan on using it for digital 16-bit art and image manipulation, which comprises of alot of heavy but short all-core workloads (usually lasting no more than a few seconds to a minute). I do occasionally do longer workloads (like video encoding or rendering out large 2D projects or animations, plus gaming), but it's not super-frequent.

I currently use a Strix B450 motherboard (I believe the DIMM slot layout is standard) with Corsair Vengeance PRO Memory (50mm height, slots 2 and 4 are occupied but I've used 1 and 3 as well in the past), and a Meshify C case (170mm cooler clearance, so it says). I think I only have room for a 1x120 radiator on the rear exhaust; the motherboard interferes with the 2x140 top slots for sure, and may interfere with the 2x120 top slots as well, and I have literally less than a millimeter of clearance between my front fans and my GPU, so no front rads.

I generally prefer air, though I'm not opposed to liquid.
I'd prefer keeping all the DIMMs unobstructed, though I could accept an overhang of my 50mm height memory.
I prefer coolers with a focus on acoustic performance.
I have no preference between either tower coolers or downdraft coolers.

I've considered the Arctic eSports coolers, the Scythe Fuma 2, some stuff from Dark Rock and Noctua.

If any of you all have suggestions or recommendations, they would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: FreeBSD was the first unix-like I ever used, so I'm a bit nostalgic about it. however, it has too many drawbacks against using Linux. ZFS is fine and all, but it's basically obsolete with NVME. device drivers in general are a disaster area. the development model with the core team is perfect for an extremely conservative OS, but that means that most meaningful changes take years to implement. outside of some network appliance stuff, it's hard to tell that it gets used anywhere meaningful. FreeBSD used to have the performance argument, but now Linux has a monopoly on the Top500. I watched the last FreeBSD developer conference and it was just bitching about how they are playing catch up with Linux. It was rather depressing.

done | tr '\n' ' ' | sed -E "s/^[ ]{1,}//;s/[ ]{2,}/ /g;s/ '/'/g;s/2 /2/g;s/(2[LDURFB])'/\1/g"

Don't buy anything OTHER THAN IBM/Lenovo ThinkPad T, X, and W/P Series if you want the Real Business Experience™
>Other business laptops are welcome in /tpg/ (Dell Latitude/Precision, HP EliteBook/ZBook)

Why ThinkPad?
>Used machines are plentiful and cheap
>Excellent keyboards, tactile feel and quiet
>Great durability: magnesium roll cage for structural integrity, with high quality plastic body panels
>Utilitarian design: e.g. indicator LEDs, 7 row keyboard layout on older models
>Docking stations that easily turns your laptop into a desktop
>Easy to repair (most models), upgrade & maintain thanks to readily available service manuals for every model, spare parts easy & cheap to obtain
>Excellent Linux & *BSD support

ThinkWiki - General info about ThinkPads/specs
https://www.thinkwiki.org/wiki/ThinkWiki

Classic models:
>X220/X230 - 12", 768p, cheap and light
>T420/T430 - 14", 900p (1080p w/mod board), Ivy Bridge support on T420 w/coreboot, quad core upgrade, classic keyboard mod on xx30 series
>T520/530; W520/530 - 15", 1080p, DTR, 32GB RAM on quad core models
>T440p/540p; W540/1 - last ThinkPads with socketed processors, easily replaceable trackpad (W541 doesn't need trackpad replacement)
>T440s/T450(s)/T460(s)/T470(s) - ultraportables, good battery life
>T480 - last ThinkPad with swappable battery, T25 keyboard mod, excellent performance/battery life, getting cheaper

Upgraded models:
>X2100 - X200/X201
>X62/X63 - X61
>T700 - T60
https://www.xyte.ch

BIOS replacement:
https://coreboot.org - T440p, X131e, X1C1, and xx30 series (no 61) or older
https://libreboot.org - similar to coreboot as of 20221214 release

Additional resources:
https://dankpads.com/tpg/
https://biosimage.booru.org
https://1vyra.in

UEFI patches:
https://github.com/digmorepaka/thinkpad-firmware-patches

Chat:
##ibmthinkpad on libera
#/tpg/ on rizon

>>90791699
That isn't a problem with C, it's a problem with the OS. You're probably thinking of Windows 95/98/ME which mapped the OS kernel into every process address space, writable, at address 0. Mapping parts of the kernel into process address spaces is common and speeds things up, but usually it's read only, doesn't include any sensitive info the kernel might have, and not at the single most common address to access accidentally. Making it writable definitely reduces the number of syscalls, and was probably a necessary optimization to make it run acceptably well on a 386, but it makes it so any ill-behaved process can corrupt the kernel, and malware can inject a rootkit simply by writing it to the right memory addresses. And then mapping it at the most common address for faults to occur at is just stupid.

>>90792231

Okay. So here's what I'm going to recommend you to do. Write a C program that produces a segmentation fault, but don't include any string literals in your source code that contain the words "segmentation fault". now compile it, and run the command "strings" on it to search the binary for the string "segmentation fault". Now run the program and observe that despite the string "segmentation fault" not occurring anywhere in the binary, it is nevertheless printed to your terminal upon the illegal memory access.

What happens is as follows:
1. Your C program performs some mov/load/store/whatever instruction to access an invalid memory address.
2. Your CPU, upon recognizing that the page for this address is not loaded in the MMU, triggers an interrupt telling the OS it needs to do about it.
3. Your OS, upon realizing that it is not legal for this process to access this page, sends a signal to the process. Without a handler, the default behavior here is for the process to terminate.
4. Your Shell, upon receiving notification that its child process was terminated by the SIGSEGV signal, prints the message "Segmentation Fault"

The segmentation fault is not produced by the C program. Rather, it is caused by everything else in response to your C program doing something dumb.

Okay, so you think that only stupid people fall over.
I can see why this approach won't get through to you.
Let's imagine instead that you are perfect, but there are other people that aren't.
Imagine that these people make a library and document it in a way that is subtly incorrect.
Now you use it in a way that the documentation permits, but is not completely supported by the implementation.
Would you rather that this:
a) cause a silent error which leads to critical security vulnerability in your software.
b) cause your software to crash occasionally, and when it does it prints out an error telling you exactly where the problem is.
This example is something that happens all the time in the real world.
It's overreaching in that it assumes you are perfect and someone else is only slightly less than perfect.

Finally I'll ask you why exactly they put an MMU in there to begin with?
It's to force C to implement the security that other languages provide.
That's because even if you only ever produce correct software, there are lots of people who make malware and can exploit these issues to cause damage.
This can't happen if you don't use languages like C.
They have to drastically change the architecture of the computer to make up for the shortcomings of C.
This issue is one that should be easily solved in software, but because of C's design decisions, it can not be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90795394
>If you can afford the overhead and/or limitations of safer languages then use them.
The thing you fundamentally don't get here, is that C is at fault and it isn't because it's too powerful.
The kinds of changes you would need to make to C to let it run in a safe way as well as an unsafe way would be semi-trivial.
99.9% of programs would be the same as they were before, and you wouldn't need an MMU, and you would be able to write an operating system almost entirely free of security vulnerabilities that runs C code.
But instead we get the brain-dead philosophy of C, where you have nothing in the language to stop you from writing your own code straight into the operating system but you just have to trust that programs (AKA unsafe hunks of binary instructions rather than a more sane format) won't do that.
This isn't just about people making mistakes; it's not about bugs; it's about people who are very deliberately writing malware.

For notes I usually split the page into 2 columns. The main notes go in the larger right column, while diagrams and important equations go in the left. If I’m looking for something in my notes I skim the left column to find what I’m broadly looking for and then read the details on the right.

>>90765057
Similar, but Cornell notes are mainly used for humanities, and i mainly take notes for sciences. Instead of filling in the left column after I’m done, I usually start each topic with a diagram illustrating it in the left column, and then explain in detail in the right column. Diagrams are very important to make notes easy to find and understand, so I usually base my detailed notes in the right column on the corresponding diagram.

I recently found some old lead pencils from the attic, probably from 40-50 years ago from grandparents' time. One of them is a plastic no-name 0.5mm lead pencil that has the most amazing attribute for drawing. It has high audible and physical feedback.
Problem is, it's a shitty and very cheap, ugly pencil, it doesn't properly extract leads, sometimes shooting them out like it's trying to kill someone, sometimes eating them, sometimes hardly spitting out lead at all.
I thought its high feedback was due to its being very old cheap lead, so I went on a retarded buying spree, but the best I could find was harder Tombow super polymer leads, which relatively offer the best feedback, but nothing like my old Taiwan shit pencil from decades ago. Turns out it's the way it's constructed that makes you feel and hear ever little grain of pulp and allows full control on the paper.
Fuck I know some of you autists can help me out here, what's a modern 0.5mm mechanical pen that has similar attributes, I can never go back to regular pencils for drawing - in particular prototype sketching. The best I found so far was a GraphGear 500 and it doesn't compare to the sound and feedback level.

I'm not sure if you'd actually like it, but imo the best graphing pencil in the market is the rOtring 800. They're really pricey at $30, but I came from a $10 0.3mm GraphGear 1000 that I managed to break in half through abuse because the inner body is plastic. The rOtring is virtually entirely metal, so it should last a while.

If you're just looking for strong feedback, I *think* that you might be best served by a fixed-sleeve pencil? They're a pain to deal with, but there should be less or no mechanism absorbing vibrations from writing. The rOtring 600 is pretty cheap ($10 or so) and might be worth a try.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90784271
I am certain that I know this as a fact. The greatest factor in overall feedback is pencil design, with second being lead type at a far lesser degree. I can say this for certain because the benchmarked 5 different lead types and degree's of hardness (2B, HB, H, H2) against several different mechanical pencils. The greatest variance was not amongst lead types, but of the pencils. It operates like the resonant properties of musical instruments, like wooden instruments or thin brass cymbals.
>>90789747
The Rotring 800 is on my wish list for when my current pens break down but I think the solid metal inner + outer build will reduce feedback.
It's ironic you mention a fixed sleeve, since my cheapo awesome pencil actually has a fixed sleeve, which I also believe contributes to the higher feedback as it "captures" the lead vibrations better.

I'm honestly surprised this is not a bigger deal. I can't explain how incredible it feels to draw light prototype sketches with high haptic feedback. IIRC from an experiment long ago wrt some Jap swordsman, visual cues process slower than touch cues and the addition of audible cues to drawing makes it quite an experience instant tactile feedback.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualisation. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.
