posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90765562
>Any tipps on getting started with docker?
Install docker, install docker-compose, find something developed by someone that you want to run, make it work. Most of the time you'll be able to find a pre-built docker-compose file for it, but learn what all the parts do.
>Just looked into it, and the first thing i read was that pihole does not work propperly as a container. Should i just keep that on the n2?
I don't really like pihole, I always found it flaky no matter what I ran it on. It does work in a container though, but you probably don't want to run its DHCP bits because of the way docker networking works.
I use NextDNS.io to accomplish the same thing, and it works on my phone remotely without having to do any funky networking stuff to avoid having an open DNS resolver on the net.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90766562
>There's nothing bad about doing lots of IO
>You're missing the point. You don't want to take a 3TB file and write to it randomly if you want to minimize fragmentation.
What're you even talking about with writing a fucking 3TB file? Anon said nothing of the sort. And for the record, since anon was looking at doing a 8x4TB array trying to write a 3TB file and worrying about fragmentation would mean his filesystem is like 90% full and he's going to have issues anyway. Also, there's nothing about RAIDZ that makes it inherently worse for a fragmented filesystem than a single drive.

>Yes, a database io profile will also do much the same, but we're not talking about the same level of $$ spend on hardware and software solutions to minimize that issue. Additionally, most db's access the data in a random way anyway, so fragmentation is much less of an issue there as long as you have proper block-size compatibility between the storage and the db pages.
If you're putting a database on a RAIDZ of spinning drives you're a retard who gets what they deserve.

>Most of these anons are wanting to access media, which is "start at the begging, and read everything until the end" which will be fastest in a non-fragmented mode.
"Fastest" is entirely irrelevant when the box can pull data off the array faster than it can put it on the network.

>I spent too much time in my day job optimizing large storage systems and the like, and I'm an autist who can't stand a slight delays when using a computer so I'm probably overkill here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90786174
Routers typically run a DNS forwarder (in case of OpenWrt, dnsmasq). By default it's set to resolve hostnames found in DHCP leases. Other queries are forwarded to a DNS server, e.g. one hosted by your ISP, or someone else like Google or Cloudflare or Quad9.
Some people don't like to forward their queries to someone else, so they run a recursively resolving DNS server. That way you're not asking Google what's the IP for xhamster.ru, but your DNS server asks root DNS servers what servers have .ru domains, then it asks those servers which nameserver has records for xhamster.ru. Something like that.

Registration and DNS are separate things. Cloudflare just makes it easy to use both on one page.
Any registrar could in theory point your domain at whatever they want, but I've never heard of anyone forcing you to use a specific one. Note that Cloudflare doesn't make you use their DNS either, and they don't make you use their DNS proxy, but they're there. I use them because I don't want to expose my actual IP, but you do you.

>>90791571
>If they did that maliciously, wouldn't it be immediately obvious by the SSL certificate being changed?
Do you examine the cert every time you go to a SSL website?

Overall though, I believe if you use their SSL Strict option then it passes through your actual cert you have at home, but it's harder to configure and you have to make sure your home certs stay good. If you use the regular SSL option it needs certs on your home stuff, but it can be self signed because it does the SSL decrypt/recrypt on their side.

posts.com: Is 10G still expensive as shit? My desktop has 10GbE, my gaming PC has 2.5GbE and my NAS has 2x1GbE with link aggregation, so I could probably get some benefit from upgrading my network, but every time I've looked at the gear, it's expensive as shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792309
10GBASE-T is still pretty expensive, because it's a niche tech for home users that want to go fast. If you can make standard fiber/DAC stuff work for your house, 10G is pretty cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792309
>>90792423
Depends what you call expensive. The NICs are less than $100, significantly more if you want two or more connections.
The switch you will absolutely need is what's expensive. A good switch is probably $200+

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: SBC cluster or refurbished thin-client cluster for light tasks? Currently using an old Dell for printing, scanning, file storage, media streaming, and door notifications. I'd like to have seperate servers for each. I might get a printer/scanner with network functionality, since I'm still rocking picrelated. Any good ones?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792473
>The NICs are less than $100, significantly more if you want two or more connections.
X520-DA2 is ~$80 with two ports.
I use a CRS317 switch, which I got for about $375 but it's probably more these days.
Finisar optics for ~$8/ea.
OM3 for ~$4/ea, depending on length.

So to get two computers and a NAS on 10G, yeah it's pretty expensive. But I have four servers (two links each), two NASes (two links each), and jumps to my copper switches. The per-port cost isn't all that bad if you're able to "spread" the switch cost around.
It's certainly a lot cheaper than 10GBASE-T for a decent number of ports. AFAIK you're still looking at hundreds of dollars per port for those.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90792473
>The switch you will absolutely need is what's expensive.
Also, if you're only going to do three things (two PCs, one NAS) you could just go with 3x dual port cards, 6x optics, 3x fibers, and make a little ring. You're looking at ~$300 in that scenario to get started, and that investment isn't wasted if you decide to add a switch later to give you more expansion capability.

5 years is average disk lifespan

This is a bigger issue with helium disks, because once most of it escapes then the drive is running out of spec, which increases the probability of it dying.

>>90785927
>I DON'T KNOW HOW TO FEEL CONFIDENT
I think it's mostly about stopping caring about failure. Which might involve getting deeper into why you're worried about it. In my case I needed pills to stop having random paranoid thoughts that I just couldn't explain no matter how deep I went (or did explain and still couldn't reject them) (pills are for ADHD in general but science checks out). Also doing what you feel like rather than what people expect of you which involves considering what you actually feel.

Or you could watch TTGL and believe in aniki that believes in you. Really don't if you're feeling down, it's mostly (fun) motivational bullshit and motivational bullshit makes you feel bad when it doesn't work (doesn't work because it's bullshit). But well, I think that is the natural path for confidence: trusting someone who will pass confidence to you. I'm not sure that happens that often though, my parents for one had no clue about parenting (multiple friends share the story).

>they thought nothing more of me, maybe "mentally unstable clown", or "depressed clown"
>Everything I was great at when I was a child, now I'm mediocre (at best) at
Basically
>being odd one out
>falling short of expectations, not reaching some supposed "potential" which other people see in you
This is way too short for any reasonable conclusion and probably could be a number of other disorders I don't know but consider AD(H)D. Check "How to ADHD", HealthyGamerGG, and search for random videos on ADHD in adulthood.

I've seen some stories of people with ADHD being misdiagnosed with depression or anxiety resulting in ineffective treatment. I myself was considering depression first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90783347
There is hope anon. How many is "barely any" friends? I was worried about not having enough friends recently (had under 5 that I would actually meet every month, then people moved around and dropped to, uh, 2 that are a couple). Then I was thinking why I need friends for some time and realized it's mostly my lack of emotion processing. Started working on that in a diary (after some initial work with a therapist) and I no longer need to meet people, I might want to meet people. I might sometimes feel lonely but now it's a little sadness rather than distress, which makes me way more capable to address it.

I suggest checking some self-help videos from HealthyGamerGG (Dr. K) or getting professional help (if you have the time and money).

import math

ratings = [1, 2, 2, 1]

def is_local_maximum(a, b, c):
    return (b > a and not b < c) or (not b < a and b > c)

def is_local_minimum(a, b, c):
    return b < a and b < c

def is_inflection_point(index):
    if index == 0 or index == len(ratings) - 1:
        return True
    
    return is_local_maximum(ratings[index - 1], ratings[index], ratings[index + 1]) \
        or is_local_minimum(ratings[index - 1], ratings[index], ratings[index + 1])

inflection_points = [is_inflection_point(index) for index in range(len(ratings))]
gap_between_inflection_points = []

current_gap = 0
for i in range(1, len(inflection_points)):
    if inflection_points[i]:
        gap_between_inflection_points.append(current_gap)
        current_gap = 0
    else:
        current_gap += 1

offset = max(gap_between_inflection_points)
inflection_point_count = sum(1 for point in inflection_points if point)

lollies_count = None
if ratings[0] < ratings[1]:
    lollies_count = math.ceil(inflection_point_count / 2) + 2 * math.floor(inflection_point_count / 2)
else:
    lollies_count = 2 * math.ceil(inflection_point_count / 2) + math.floor(inflection_point_count / 2)

lollies_count = lollies_count + offset

print(lollies_count)

I believe this works.
The code is a bit ugly but right now my GNOME is shitting the bed badly (frozen mouse) so it's painful to edit.

OP you are not clear about your requirements, so I implemented the rule that Pepes of the same rank have the same number of lollies.

#lang racket

(module+ test
  (require rackunit)

  (check-equal? (minimum-lollies #(1 1 1))
                3)
  (check-equal? (minimum-lollies #(1 0 2))
                5)
  (check-equal? (minimum-lollies #(1 2 2 1))
                6)
  (check-equal? (minimum-lollies #(1 3 2 2 1))
                10)
  (check-equal? (minimum-lollies #(1 2 2 3 2 2 1))
                13)
  (check-equal? (minimum-lollies #(5 4 3 2 1 0))
                21)
 )

(define (diff-from-previous ratings)
  (for/vector ([i (in-range 0 (vector-length ratings))])
    (if (zero? i)
        0
        (let ([current (vector-ref ratings i)]
              [previous (vector-ref ratings (- i 1))])
          (cond
            [(< previous current) +1]
            [(> previous current) -1]
            [else 0])))))

(define (diff-from-first ratings)
  (for/fold
   ([vec (make-vector 0)])
   ([i (in-range 0 (vector-length ratings))])
    (if (zero? i)
        (vector-append vec (make-vector 1 0))
        (let ([current (vector-ref ratings i)]
              [previous (vector-ref vec (- i 1))])
          (vector-append vec (make-vector 1 (+ previous current)))))))

(define (minimum-lollies ratings)
  (let* ((from-first (vector->list (diff-from-first (diff-from-previous ratings))))
         (minval (argmin min from-first))
         (adjusted (map (lambda (n) (+ (+ 1 (- minval)) n)) from-first)))
    (apply + adjusted)))

import math

ratings = [1, 2, 2, 3, 2, 2,1]

def is_local_minimum(left, center, right):
    return (left is None or center <= left) and (right is None or center <= right)

def is_local_maximum(left, center, right):
    return (left is None or center >= left) and (right is None or center >= right)

def normalize(ratings):
    sorted_ratings = sorted(set(ratings))
    new_ratings = {rating: (index + 1) for index, rating in enumerate(sorted_ratings)}

    return [new_ratings[rating] for rating in ratings]

def simplify(ratings):
    simplified = []
    for i in range(len(ratings)):
        left = ratings[i - 1] if i > 0 else None
        right = ratings[i + 1] if i < len(ratings) - 1 else None
        center = ratings[i]

        if is_local_minimum(left, center, right):
            simplified.append(-1)
        elif is_local_maximum(left, center, right):
            simplified.append(999999)
        else:
            simplified.append(center)
    
    return simplified

ratings = simplify(ratings)
ratings = normalize(ratings)

print(sum(ratings))

def min_bananas(ratings):

#include<iostream>

void pepesfn(int index, int* pepes, int* lollis, size_t len, bool r, int* h) {
  int left = -1;
  int right = -1;
  if (index-1 >= 0) left  = pepes[index-1];
  if (index+1 < len) right = pepes[index+1];
  if (!lollis[index]) {
    lollis[index] = 1;
    *h = (*h) + 1;
  }
  if (left != -1) {
    while (pepes[index-1]> pepes[index] && lollis[index-1] <= lollis[index]) {
      lollis[index-1]++;
      *h = (*h) + 1;
    }
    pepesfn(index-1, pepes, lollis, len, false, h);
  }
  if (right != -1 && r) {
    while (pepes[index+1] > pepes[index] && lollis[index+1] <= lollis[index]) {
      lollis[index+1]++;
      *h = (*h) + 1;
    }
    pepesfn(index+1, pepes, lollis, len, r, h);
  }
}

int main() {
  int pepes[] = {1, 3, 2, 2, 1};
  size_t pn = sizeof(pepes)/sizeof(int);
  int left, right;
  int lollis[pn];
  for (int i=0; i<pn; i++) lollis[i] = 0;
  int max = 0;
  pepesfn(0, pepes, lollis, pn, true, &max);
  printf("%d", max);
  return 0;
}

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90772825
Its funny, because supposed security experts make the same mistake as you, of thinking the method works because the way you generated a password is a secret, and thus the popularity of the method somehow weakens it. The intuition of the method is that most people don't know what a potential password cracker knows about passwords, so they can't possibly defend against that. I was looking at a popular password list the other day, and saw a seemingly random number sequence near the top of the list. So, I looked it up, and it turns out it comes from a television show. Every single person using that password probably thought they were a genius, but in fact they were just a sheep going to slaughter. If you approach password generation in this way, of trying to "one up" crackers, then you may get off fine, or you may do the exact same thing as millions of other people, and make a password that gets guessed immediately. On the other hand, if you assume the cracker knows the exact method used to generate the password, but doesn't have access to the random seed, then you can put a strict lower bound on how long it will take them to crack the password. From there, you can choose exactly how secure you want your password to be.

posts.com:
>>90773643
>For hardware you control, one password for everything.
Or you can have only one password for a dedicated "master" computer: disable the root user and make it so the only way to log in is your init automatically logging you in, and make sudo/doas work without password. This is fine because you will be using full headerless & hashless disk encryption with the keyfile and boot partition on a usb drive.
Use that dedicated master machine to connect to your home wifi and boot your other machines using Netboot. You won't have to enter a password to boot them since you can send the encryption keyfile inside the initramfs you send through netboot.
On the other machines do the same thing: disable root user and have init log you in automatically. Here's the catch: instead of disabling the sudo password, you can use your master machine to authenticate - this is why it's better to use a SBC or a laptop for the master machine, so you can authenticate easily by just pressing one button or key.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90773049
Combining multiple dictionary words into a phrase through brute force is somewhat comparable to individual character brute force attacks. Obviously there are more words than characters, but if you narrow your dictionary down to common words or even pick out certain phrases then you can get results surprisingly quick for 3-4 word passwords. In effect you would need to use some absurdly long (character-wise) passwords or go out of your way to use weird words.
So while you're right that a dictionary attack isn't actually combining words, the kind of brute force attack that they're talking about is still a real threat that makes the xkcd password strategy less convenient.
>>90773409
>>90773491
Random but memorizable gibberish is what I use for my master password. Something like "KipFah42_Vormeen" would be secure and simple to type. The xkcd comic comes from a time when the convenience of easy memorization was worth the length trade-off since you were expected to memorize all of your passwords; now with the master password philosophy I'd argue it's more convenient to go with a shorter gibberish password since it saves you keystrokes while still being secure enough. Long multiword phrases just aren't as convenient when you only have to memorize a single password.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90791960
the tl;dr is engineering a design which is compatible with an existing design but that doesn't directly use any of the sources used by the original design, it's "clean" in that it uses no copyrighted information from the original design
take Wine as a very well known and large example, Wine is intended to be a drop-in replacement for windows userspace (win32), yet not only does it use no components from windows directly, it is also designed without studying the internals of any windows components either, that is, that can't say, decompile windows binaries and literally copy routines out of them, because that would be "dirty" and likely copyright infringing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90791955
As a note, the SM64 decompilation was entirely clean-room, meaning the people working on it didn't use anything out of the gigaleaks even if they contained original source for the game. That combined with how they posted only the engine source code and require you to provide a ROM for it to extract all content and assets from, makes it harder for Nintendo to do anything about it. After all, this is just C code that these people wrote that is capable of making use of the assets from the game, and happens to compile to a byte-identical copy of the game ROM when combined with the correct assets and compiler flags. No actual Nintendo-originated code or data is being distributed.
